Ordinals (1st, 2nd, 3rd etc) for Rust
=====================================

[<img alt="github" src="https://img.shields.io/badge/github-dtolnay/ordinal-8da0cb?style=for-the-badge&labelColor=555555&logo=github" height="20">](https://github.com/dtolnay/ordinal)
[<img alt="crates.io" src="https://img.shields.io/crates/v/ordinal.svg?style=for-the-badge&color=fc8d62&logo=rust" height="20">](https://crates.io/crates/ordinal)
[<img alt="docs.rs" src="https://img.shields.io/badge/docs.rs-ordinal-66c2a5?style=for-the-badge&labelColor=555555&logoColor=white&logo=data:image/svg+xml;base64," height="20">](https://docs.rs/ordinal)
[<img alt="build status" src="https://img.shields.io/github/workflow/status/dtolnay/ordinal/CI/master?style=for-the-badge" height="20">](https://github.com/dtolnay/ordinal/actions?query=branch%3Amaster)

This crate provides a type `Ordinal<T>` that formats an [`Integer`] type `T` as
an [ordinal number] (1st, 2nd, 3rd etc).

[`Integer`]: https://docs.rs/num-integer/0.1/num_integer/trait.Integer.html
[ordinal number]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ordinal_number_%28linguistics%29

```toml
[dependencies]
ordinal = "0.2"
```

## Example

```rust
use ordinal::Ordinal;

fn main() {
    assert_eq!("2nd", Ordinal(2).to_string());
}
```
